title.narrative: Integrated Coastal Zone Management for sustainable development in Central Java

description.narrative: Long-term impact: Water is used sustainably and equitably, ensuring the needs of all sectors and the environment. Medium-term impact that will contribute to this: (l) Education system (TVET/HE) is of good quality, relevant and accessible (SDG 4): (Il) (Il) Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable (SDG 17); (Ill) (Ill) Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce. Outcome of the project: A. TVET/HE organisations (in the selected partner countries and in NL) peform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment (in line with country / regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness).
OKP-ICP-IDN-103154

The Central Java Province (CJP), responsible for managing the North Coast of Java is facing serious challenges, mainly as a consequence of land subsidence caused by overexploitation of groundwater. This results in the disappearance of mangrove forests and increased coastal erosion and flooding, threatening coastal communities and urban areas. It is obvious that these problems can only be addressed by using an integrated approach in spatial planning and environmental management. Therefore, there is an urgent need for highly qualified staff capable to support CJP with developing and implementing an Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) approach to manage the North Coast in a sustainable way. Diponegoro University (UNDIP), the main university in Central Java has a very good reputation in education, research and community services, but does not yet offer education in ICZM. This project will support UNDIP with integrating their disciplinary expertise into an ICZM Centre. This Centre, jointly with the project partners, is expected to play a pivotal role in developing and rolling out the concept of ICZM in Central Java at all levels (kampung, kecamatan, kabupaten, kota and provinsi) by raising awareness, as well as by offering educational programmes, initiating integrated research projects and serving as a data centre.

The main target group of the project will be staff of UNDIP, in particular university lecturers that will be trained in applying their expertise in a multidisciplinary, integrated approach. However, it should be noted that also the Dutch lecturers will benefit from this activity to further develop integrated approaches in their professional life. The second group to benefit from the project are the various stakeholders: 1) managers at provincial and district level, 2) research and development agencies from different ministries, 3) economic stakeholders, 4) local consultants and contractors and 5) coastal communities. All these groups will not only be involved in the needs assessment, and therefore will have an impact on the outcome of the project, but they will also directly receive the benefits from the newly developed professional and community-oriented training activities. And finally, MSc students who want to pursue a career in ICZM will be offered a challenging curriculum in ICZM to prepare them for their professional life. By linking up with HAPPI (Coastal Management Expert Organization), the ICZM Centre will play a role in the certification of consultants and contractors that will be involved in ICZM projects in the future.

Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 2. Bottlenecks, deviations and possible adjustments

description.narrative: Analysis of bottlenecks which (may) have an implication on the achievement of project outputs and outcomes. Give an explanation on deviations from planning, and mention factors which had an effect on the project performance. Please elaborate on the measures that were taken in order to address the causes for deviations, delays, etc. In case of deviations in the financial statement of more than 20% of the annual budget per output and project management budget lines and of more than 20% per cost category, please explain the effect on the achievement of the planned outputs and outcomes. On the basis of the information presented, you can argue the need for, and propose adjustments to the planning. If applicable you may attach an adjusted project budget for the remaining project period. N.B. Proposals to change planned outputs need formal approval from Nuffic in advance. It is therefore essential to request approval in writing timely, and not to wait until you submit the annual report.

actual.value: No start was made yet with designing a data base structure. This will be done in 2020. A start has been made with developing various training activities (professional courses and outreach activities), but the real implementation is foreseen for 2020 and 2021. CJP staff has been trained in relevant topics at IHE Delft and the training of Undip staff will start in 2020. The project is more or less developing as planned and no real adjustments are needed. NB due to the corona crisis the situation has changed considerably and the project will face serious delays.

title.narrative: 8. Mid-term evaluation

description.narrative: For projects with a duration of more than two (2) years, the grant recipient must submit an external mid-term evaluation. The external mid-term evaluation must comply with the applicable guidelines for the Mid Term Evaluation available on www.nuffic.nl. The mid-term evaluation forms a formal go no-go moment, aside from the fact that Nuffic can withdraw, amend or settle the grant on a lower amount and demand the return of all or part of any sum it has already transferred if the grant recipient fails to fulfil the obligations and conditions attached to the grant or if the output(s) and/or the outcome(s) and/or the activities for which the grant was awarded have not or will not be achieved, have not or will not be achieved in time or have not or will not be achieved in full.

title.narrative: 12. Final report

description.narrative:
If this report is a final report, the report should also focus on the following: • Description of the achievements in the total project period in relation to the planned project output(s) and outcome(s). Assess the relevance of the outputs (impact of the project achievements on the development of the counterpart organisation and on policy priorities at national level). • Assessment of the project approach (strategy) on effectiveness and efficiency (the relationship between the resource allocation and activities and the achieved objectives). Comment also on the risk assumptions made at the start. • Description of changes in the project context that have had an influence on the implementation of the project. • Analysis of bottlenecks which have occurred in the implementation of the project and the measures which have been taken to remove the bottlenecks. • Sustainability. Describe the measures that have been taken and measures still to be taken to ensure the sustainability of the project outputs. Describe how project output(s) and outcome(s) will be continued, institutionalised and financed. Describe the factors that will have influence on sustainability. • Name, if applicable, the spin-offs/success stories (refer to the corresponding work sheet in the achievement annex). • Formulation of lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
In their email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the Lead partner Dutch consortium and Lead partner consortium country A on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 10. Follow-up on conditions and recommendations

description.narrative: In the case of AAC recommendations, grant conditions, conditions / recommendations in previous decision letters or monitoring visit matters, please comment upon them here.

actual.value:
As an additional obligation for the grant award, the log-frame and (sub)outputs have been revised to make them SMART. As a result, the budget had to be revised as well. The total budget remained the same, but planned expenses are divided slightly different over the various outputs.
_Organizational strenghtening_ As requested, the team of experts will be complemented by expertise in organisational strengthening. Budget for this activity has been earmarked. MDF Indonesia has been approached to come up with a plan for combined training and coaching _Didactical expertise_ All staff from IHE Delft, Radboud University and Deltares that are involved in supporting the development of educational activities and training of Undip staff have their University Teaching Qualification, or equivalent, and are well equipped to apply student centred approaches in their teaching. Therefore, no additional expertise is considered to be necessary.

title.narrative: 3. Contribution to achieving the project outcomes and impact of the OKP programme in your country

description.narrative: In this section you are requested to describe the contributions which the project has made in achieving project outcomes and impacts of the Orange Knowledge programme in your country as described in the Orange Knowledge Country Plan of Implementation (CPI). To what extent does the project collaborate with other stakeholders within the same (sub)sector? In addition, project parties have to report on the coherence of their project activities with interventions supported by other donors/organisations.

actual.value: It is too early now to describe impacts of the project. The real impacts will be achieved after the ICZM Centre will become operational and will start its training and outreach activities. The Undip project director attends the regular coordination meetings organized from the MoU Water. There are contacts with the RVO funded project ICZM Central Java, which, amongst others, resulted in a joint fieldtrip in the Netherlands. There is a direct link with the Central Java Province and active involvement of relevant stakeholders, mainly from the project site Pekalongan. The Governor of Central Java was actively involved in selecting Pekalongan as the pilot study site.

title.narrative: 0. External factors and risks

description.narrative: In this section you are requested to: a) discuss how you have managed the risks and assumptions which were identified at the start phase of the project, and b) explain any risks and assumptions that were not foreseen during the project formulation (articulation) but you have identified as likely to have an impact on the achievements of the project objectives. c) assess the actual relevance of the outcomes of the project, and of the viability of achieving the original outcomes, as stipulated in the approved project proposal. d) address any developments in the local context that may affect the project directly or indirectly (new or adjusted policies, political and socio-economic developments etc.)

actual.value: At the start of the project, it was not clear if there were any administrative procedures that could harm the establishment of the ICZM Centre early during the project implementation. However, the project got full support from Undip authorities and the ICZM Centre will officially be launched in March 2020. With support from the Governor of Central Java Province, a case study area (Pekalongan) was identified directly during the inception phase. Stakeholders from all levels (both from CJP and Pekalongan) actively participated in the actor assessment and needs assessment workshops. Staff from all partners were involved in the curriculum development workshop, which resulted in a concrete plan for the development of training modules and a pilot training in May 2020. The IHE MSc students that went to Undip to carry out their research projects got full support from local communities and institutes as well as from Undip staff and students. Thus it seems that there is a conducive environment for the project to achieve most of its planned outcomes. The only activity that was delayed, is the establishment of the data base. This will be taken up in 2020.

title.narrative: 11. Other relevant information

description.narrative: In this section, you may cover additional issues related to the project.

actual.value:
As it was not possible to report on outputs 2 and 3, please see below. Output 2.1. An outline of a curriculum has been developed and is ready for further elaboration. Output 2.2. A first didactical course has been provided for Undip staff. Output 2.3. Under construction as outcome of the curriculum development workshop. Output 3. Two staff of CJP started their MSc studies at IHE Delft and will carry out their thesis research starting October 2020. Five IHE Delft MSc students have carried out their MSc thesis research under this project. Their results will be available in April 2020.
The indicator "Number of people having enough water of good quality throughout the year" was not included in the SRS. As this is not considered as an output affected by the project, no number has been given during the proposal submission.
For some results and indicators no appropriate baseline levels were provided during proposal submission. This should have been done during 2019, but the project failed to do this. This needs to be repaired during 2020.
For some results and indicators it was difficult to collect the right information. Therefore they were set at 0, but they will be corrected when possible.
IHE Delft organized a training for CJP staff (1F/10M) on "Modernized irrigation and water accounting for coastal area in Central Java". The costs (€25,613) were covered by CJP and can be considered as co-funding.

title.narrative: 9. Visibility and communication

description.narrative: RSR allows the project partners to place ‘updates’ on the project page. The better the pictures and narratives are, the easier it will be to take stakeholders along in the journey and story of change of each project and create visibility for the Orange Knowledge programme. Nuffic asks all projects to upload project-specific updates in RSR at the very minimum once a year. Nuffic sees theses update as an opportunity for the partners and the projects to learn from each other: from their successes and drawback.

title.narrative: 4. Sustainability

description.narrative: Sustainability is an issue that requires full attention right from the start of the project. Please highlight measures taken and achievements made during the reporting period, which are likely to contribute to the sustainability of the project outputs in four criteria: organisational, financial, technical and educational.

actual.value: Organizational: Undip has appointed two staff members as director and deputy director of the ICZM Centre and an office was made available. Thus there is clear commitment from the university. Contacts with MDF have been established to provide the staff of the Centre with additional management training and support. Financial: When the Centre will become operational, income will be generated by providing professional training and advisory services. During the above mentioned management training this issues will be addressed as well. Technical: the budget available for investments will be dedicated mainly to support the Centre with its operational activities. A plan will be made and implemented in 2020. Educational: In view of the existing problems and future challenges, there will be a long-lasting need for professional and academic knowledge to manage the coastal zones of Indonesia.

title.narrative: 7. Holistic approach towards capacity development

description.narrative: What progress is being made in strengthening the overall capacity of the requesting organisation to deliver the products and services which are demanded by the labour market and society in general. Please differentiate between institutional, organisational, individual and educational capacity needs. please highlight the progress in procurement of investments and explain how the hardware is integrated in teaching/education. What successes and or constraints can be reported in relation to integrated capacity development and the 5 Capabilities ?

actual.value: Not much progress has been made yet, nor have investments been made. This will be a major concern for 2020. However, the various workshops that have been organized in preparation of the curriculum development involved representatives of various stakeholders and thus contributed to a more holistic approach to the educational programmes that will be developed.

title.narrative: 6. Labour market and entrepreneurship

description.narrative: What progress is being made to relate higher education and TVET to the demands of the labour market? What are the prospects of graduates to find employment or to become self-employed?

actual.value: An extensive stakeholder consultation has been part of the activities. This also included potential employers. This aspect will get follow-up during the first pilot training in May 2020.

title.narrative: 5. Opportunities for marginalised and vulnerable groups and gender perspective

description.narrative: What progress is being made to the achievement of better opportunities for marginalised and vulnerable groups, and of gender equality in project implementation as well as in the contents and delivery of education and training activities?

actual.value:
During the stakeholder and needs assessment workshops, various stakeholders were actively involved, representing vulnerable groups as well as gender perspectives.
The following has been provided by the Office of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries of Central Java Province as co-funding: training and work equipment assistance in 6 (six) North Coast districts and 1 (one) South Coast Regency, namely: Brebes Regency - equipment for boiling salt processing. Pekalongan Regency - natural batik equipment Jepara Regency (Karimunjawa) - fish processing equipment Rembang Regency - natural batik equipment Pati Regency - natural batik equipment Batang Regency - seashell handicraft equipment Cilacap Regency - fish processing equipment.
An advisor from Radboud University was consulted to support this aspect. Early 2020 an analysis will be made at Undip of the available expertise and commitment, which will serve as a basis for follow-up activities.

title.narrative: 1. Project progress and achievement
